questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leucoerythroblastic blood picture Myelodysplastic syndrome usually results in pancytopenia rather than leukoerythroblastic blood picture.

Highyeild:

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS has refractory cytopenia and most commonly presents with hypercellular bone marrow . Classification: Refractory Cytopenia of Unilineage Dysplasia Refractory Cytopenia of Multilineage Dysplasia Refractory Anemia with Ring Sideroblasts Refractory Anemia with Excess Blasts MDS with isolated 5q deletions Characteristic changes were seen in MDS in different lineages: Erythroid lineage Ring erythroblast and sideroblast Dimorphic RBCs Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with nuclear budding and bridging Granulocytic lineage Dohle bodies Pseudo pegler huet anomaly Megakaryocytic lineage Giant platelets Pawn ball megakaryocyte Most common cytogenetic abnormality in MDS: 5q deletion Hallmark genetic abnormality: Loss of RPS 14 All types of MDS can progress to AML but increased incidence with therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Pawn ball megakaryocytes. Correct . Option: C. Pseudo pelger huet cells. Correct . Option: D. Transformation to AML. Correct .

Solution:

All of the above Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet neutrophils: bilobed hypo-granular dysplastic neutrophils seen in Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), Accelerated phase of CML, AML with dysplastic maturation . Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells, neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes instead of the normal three to four, are observed at the top and bottom of this field.

Highyeild:

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS has refractory cytopenia and most commonly presents with hypercellular bone marrow . Classification: Refractory Cytopenia of Unilineage Dysplasia Refractory Cytopenia of Multilineage Dysplasia Refractory Anemia with Ring Sideroblasts Refractory Anemia with Excess Blasts MDS with isolated 5q deletions

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Myelodysplastic syndrome. Correct . Option: B. Accelerated phase of CML. Correct . Option: C. AML with dysplastic maturation. Correct .

Extraedge:

Characteristic changes were seen in MDS in different lineages: Erythroid lineage Ring erythoblast and sideroblast Dimorphic RBCs Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with nuclear budding and bridging Granulocytic lineage Dohle bodies Pseudo pegler huet anomaly Megakaryocytic lineage Giant platelets Pawn ball megakaryocyte Most common cytogenetic abnormality in MDS: 5q deletion Hallmark genetic abnormality: Loss of RPS 14 All types of MDS can progress to AML but increased incidence with therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) .

questions.text: In myelodysplastic syndrome, ring sideroblast is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mitochondria In myelodysplastic syndrome, ring sideroblast is seen in Mitochondria Within the erythroid series, common abnormalities include ring sideroblasts and erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules in Prussian blue –stained aspirates or biopsies.

Highyeild:

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS has refractory cytopenia and most commonly presents with hypercellular bone marrow . Classification: Refractory Cytopenia of Unilineage Dysplasia Refractory Cytopenia of Multilineage Dysplasia Refractory Anemia with Ring Sideroblasts Refractory Anemia with Excess Blasts MDS with isolated 5q deletions Characteristic changes were seen in MDS in different lineages: Erythroid lineage Ring erythroblast and sideroblast Dimorphic RBCs Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with nuclear budding and bridging Granulocytic lineage Dohle bodies Pseudo pegler huet anomaly Megakaryocytic lineage Giant platelets Pawn ball megakaryocyte Most common cytogenetic abnormality in MDS: 5q deletion Hallmark genetic abnormality: Loss of RPS 14 All types of MDS can progress to AML but increased incidence with therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Golgi body. Incorrect . Option: C. Nuclear membrane. Incorrect . Option: D. ER. Incorrect .

questions.text: Which of the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of juvenile myelomonocytic leukaemia -

options.label: B
options.text: Increased haemoglobin F levels for age

options.label: D
options.text: GM-CSF hypersensitivity of myeloid progenitors in vitro

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of BCR-ABL fusion gene
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of BCR-ABL fusion gene The presence of BCR-ABL fusion gene is not compatible with a diagnosis of juvenile myelomonocytic leukaemia (JMML) The Philadelphia chromosome is seen in CML & some cases of ALL.

Highyeild:

MPN-MDS overlap: Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukaemia (CMML) Atypical Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (aCML): BCR-ABL negative Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukaemia (JMML) MDS/MPN with ring sideroblasts and thrombocytosis (MPN/MDS-RS-T) MDS/MPN unclassified

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Peripheral blood monocytosis, more than ≥1 × 10^9/L. Correct . Option: B. Increased haemoglobin F levels for age. Correct . Option: D. GM-CSF hypersensitivity of myeloid progenitors in vitro. Correct .

Extraedge:

Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukaemia (JMML): JMML is primarily a disease of early childhood and is included, along with CMML, in the “MDS/MPN” WHO category. Both CMML and JMML feature leukocytosis , monocytosis , and hepatosplenomegaly . Additional characteristic features in JMML include thrombocytopenia and elevated fetal haemoglobin . Myeloid progenitors in JMML display GM-CSF hypersensitivity that has been attributed to dysregulated RAS/MAPK signalling. 2016 revised WHO diagnostic criteria for JMML requires the presence of peripheral blood monocyte count ≥1 × 10^9/L , < 20% blasts in blood or BM , splenomegaly , and absence of BCR-ABL1

questions.text: Which is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in adult myelodysplastic syndrome(MDS) -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5q- The cytogenetic anomalies in MDS include deletion (5q) , most common -7, +8, -5 and -18 as the most frequent changes, in the order shown.

Highyeild:

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS): MDS has refractory cytopenia and most commonly presents with hypercellular bone marrow . Classification: Refractory Cytopenia of Unilineage Dysplasia Refractory Cytopenia of Multilineage Dysplasia Refractory Anemia with Ring Sideroblasts Refractory Anemia with Excess Blasts MDS with isolated 5q deletions Characteristic changes were seen in MDS in different lineages: Erythroid lineage Ring erythroblast and sideroblast Dimorphic RBCs Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with nuclear budding and bridging Granulocytic lineage Dohle bodies Pseudo pegler huet anomaly Megakaryocytic lineage Giant platelets Pawn ball megakaryocyte Most common cytogenetic abnormality in MDS: 5q deletion Hallmark genetic abnormality: Loss of RPS 14 All types of MDS can progress to AML but increased incidence with therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Trisomy 8. Incorrect . Option: B. 20q-. Incorrect . Option: D. Monosomy 7. Incorrect .
